Agenda detail: DEVELOPMENT AND INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC COOPERATION: INTEGRATION OF THE ECONOMIES IN TRANSITION INTO THE WORLD ECONOMY
cosponsored countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Krygyzstan, Latvia, Lithuania, Nicaragua, Poland, Republic of Moldova, Romania, Slovakia, Tajikistan, Russian Federation, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Turkmenistan, Ukraine and United States of America
body title detail: Integration of the economies in transition into the
body text: world economy The General Assembly, Reaffirming its resolutions 47/175 and 47/187 of 22 December 1992 and all its other relevant resolutions, Noting the relevant decisions of the Governing Council of the United Nations Development Programme, 1/ decision B (48) of 26 April 1993, adopted by the Economic Commission for Europe, 2/ and resolution 49/1 of 29 April 1993, adopted by the Economic and Social Commission of Asia and the Pacific, 3/ Taking note of the report of the Secretary-General concerning the role of the United Nations system in addressing problems facing countries with economies 1/ Official Records of the Economic and Social Council, 1993, Supplement No. 15 (E/1993/35), annex I. Ibid., Supplement No. 17 (E/1993/37), chap. IV. Ibid., Supplement No. 16 (E/1993/36), chap. IV. 171193 in transition, including the difficulties that those countries are encountering as they integrate their economies into the world economy, 4/ 1. Reaffirms the need for the full integration of the countries with economies in transition, as well as all other countries, into the world economy, in particular through improved market access for their exports of goods and services; such integration will support the systemic transformation of countries with economies in transition towards market-oriented policies and will, simultaneously, have a positive impact on world trade and global economic growth and development; 2. Requests the Secretary-General to strengthen - within existing resources and through appropriate arrangements within the United Nations Secretariat - the ability of the United Nations system to conduct analytical activities and provide policy advice and technical assistance to the countries with economies in transition and to promote and enhance mutual cooperation with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, within their respective mandates; 3. Also requests the Secretary-General to study - within the scope of the implementation of the present resolution and while continuing the existing cooperation with relevant international institutions and entities - possible areas of economic and technical cooperation among countries with economies in transition, as well as with the developing countries, identifying the role the United Nations system could play in this field, with a view to encouraging greater participation by those countries in the world economy; 4. Further requests the Secretary-General to submit to the General Assembly at its forty-ninth session, and biennially thereafter, a report on the implementation of the present resolution. A/48/317.

Agenda detail: STRENGTHENING OF INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION AND COORDINATION OF EFFORTS TO STUDY, MITIGATE AND MINIMIZE THE CONSEQUENCES OF THE CHERNOBYL DISASTER
cosponsored countries: Barbados, Belarus, Colombia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Hungary, Japan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Malaysia, Marshall Islands, Namibia, Republic of Korea, Republic of Moldova, Romania, Russian Federation, Slovakia, Turkey and Ukraine
body title detail: Strengthening of international cooperation and coordination of efforts to study, mitigate and minimize the consequences of the Chernobyl disaster
body text: The General Assembly, Reaffirming its resolution 45/190 of 21 December 1990, 46/150 of 18 December 1991 and 47/165 of 18 December 1992, Recalling Economic and Social Council resolutions 1990/50 of 13 July 1990, 1991/51 of 26 July, 1992/38 of 30 July 1992 and decision 1993/232 of 22 and 30 July 1993, Taking note of the decisions adopted by the organs, organizations and programmes of the United Nations system in the implementation of its resolutions 45/190, 46/150 and 47/165, Noting with appreciation the contribution made by Member States and by organizations of the United Nations system in the development of cooperation to mitigate and minimize the consequences of the Chernobyl disaster, the activities of regional and other organizations, as well as bilateral activities and those of the non-governmental sector, Bearing in mind the communiqué on the meeting of the Governments of Belarus, the Russian Federation and Ukraine and the United Nations Coordinator of International Cooperation on Chernobyl, held at Minsk on 26 May 1993, 1/ Recognizing the importance of providing international support to the ongoing national efforts to mitigate and minimize the radiological, health, socio-economic, psychological and environmental consequences of the Chernobyl disaster, taking into consideration the subsequent social, economic and other changes that have occurred in the countries most affected by the Chernobyl disaster, Taking note of the report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of General Assembly resolution 47/165 and the conclusions of the analytical review of all United Nations activities to study, mitigate and minimize the consequences of the Chernobyl disaster, 2/ 1. Requests the Secretary-General to continue the activities related to the follow-up to its resolutions 45/190, 46/150 and 47/165 and, in particular, to continue to maintain close contacts with the Commission of the European Communities and regional and other relevant organizations, with a view to encouraging the regular exchange of information, cooperation, coordination and complementarity in the multilateral and bilateral efforts in those areas, while implementing programmes and specific projects; 2. Invites the Secretary-General to consider the possibility of a further exchange of information between the coordination mechanisms and Member States on the activities related to Chernobyl; 3. Requests the Secretary-General to submit to the General Assembly for consideration at its fiftieth session, under a separate agenda item, a report on the implementation of the present resolution. See A/48/406, sect. B. A/48/406.
